Title: Are they really listening? Watch their blinks
Description:
Blinking is something people do automatically, much like breathing, without giving it much thought. While most scientific research on blinking has focused on eyesight, a new study from Concordia University explores a different connection. The research looks at how blinking relates to cognitive processes, including how the brain filters out background noise so we can focus on speech in busy environments.

The findings were published in the journal Trends in Hearing. In the paper, researchers outline two experiments designed to observe how blinking behavior changes when people are exposed to different listening conditions.

Fewer Blinks Signal Greater Mental Effort

The researchers discovered that people tend to blink less when they are working harder to understand speech in noisy settings. This reduction in blinking appears to reflect the mental effort involved in listening closely during everyday conversations. Importantly, the pattern stayed the same regardless of lighting conditions -- participants blinked at similar rates whether the room was bright, dim, or dark.

"We wanted to know if blinking was impacted by environmental factors and how it related to executive function," says lead author P√©n√©lope Coupal, an Honours student at the Laboratory for Hearing and Cognition. "For instance, is there a strategic timing of a person's blinks so they would not miss out on what is being said?"

The results showed that blinking does appear to be timed in a purposeful way.

"We don't just blink randomly," says Coupal. "In fact, we blink systematically less when salient information is presented."

Measuring Blinks During Challenging Listening Tasks

The study included nearly 50 adult participants. Each person sat in a soundproof room and focused on a fixed cross displayed on a screen. They listened to short spoken sentences through headphones while the level of background noise changed. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) ranged from very quiet to highly distracting.

Participants wore eye-tracking glasses that captured every blink and recorded exactly when each blink occurred. Researchers divided each listening session into three phases: before the sentence played, while it was playing, and immediately afterward.

Blink rates dropped most noticeably during the sentences themselves, compared to the moments before and after. The decrease was strongest when background noise was loudest and speech was hardest to understand.

Lighting Does Not Explain the Effect

In a second experiment, the team tested blinking behavior again while changing the lighting conditions. Participants completed the listening tasks in dark, medium, and brightly lit rooms, across different SNR levels. The same blink suppression pattern appeared each time.

This consistency showed that the effect was driven by cognitive demands rather than changes in how much light entered the eyes.

Although individuals differed widely in how often they blinked overall -- some participant blinked as little as 10 times per minute, while others may have blinked 70 times per minute -- the overall trend was clear and statistically meaningful.

Blinks as a Tool for Studying Brain Function

Earlier research linking eye behavior to mental effort mostly relied on pupil dilation (pupillometry). In many cases, blinks were treated as unwanted interruptions and removed from the data. In contrast, this study revisited existing pupillometry data and focused directly on blink timing and frequency.

The researchers say the results support using blink rate as a simple and low-effort way to measure cognitive function, both in controlled laboratory experiments and in real-world situations.

"Our study suggests that blinking is associated with losing information, both visual and auditory," says co-author Mickael Deroche, an associate professor in the Department of Psychology.

"That is presumably why we suppress blinking when important information is coming. But to be fully convincing, we need to map out the precise timing and pattern of how visual/auditory information is lost during a blink. This is the logical next step, and a study is being led by postdoctoral fellow Charlotte Bigras. But these findings are far from trivial."

Yue Zhang contributed to this research.

Materials provided by Concordia University. Note: Content may be edited for style and length.

Title: MIT scientists strip cancer of its sugar shield
Description:
A research team from MIT and Stanford University has developed a new technique designed to push the immune system to go after tumor cells. The strategy is aimed at helping cancer immunotherapy succeed in far more patients than it does today.

At the center of the work is a way to undo a built in "brake" that tumors can trigger to keep immune cells from attacking. That brake is tied to sugars called glycans, which sit on the surface of cancer cells.

The scientists found that blocking these glycans with proteins known as lectins can greatly strengthen immune activity against cancer cells. To do this in a targeted way, they built multifunctional molecules called AbLecs that pair a lectin with an antibody that homes in on tumors.

"We created a new kind of protein therapeutic that can block glycan-based immune checkpoints and boost anti-cancer immune responses," says Jessica Stark, the Underwood-Prescott Career Development Professor in the departments of Biological Engineering and Chemical Engineering. "Because glycans are known to restrain the immune response to cancer in multiple tumor types, we suspect our molecules could offer new and potentially more effective treatment options for many cancer patients."

Stark, who is also a member of MIT's Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, led the study as the paper's lead author. Carolyn Bertozzi, a Stanford professor of chemistry and director of the Sarafan ChEM Institute, served as the senior author. The findings were published in Nature Biotechnology.

How Cancer Uses Immune Brakes

One of the biggest goals in cancer treatment is teaching the immune system to spot tumor cells and eliminate them. A major group of immunotherapy drugs called checkpoint inhibitors works by interrupting the interaction between two proteins, PD-1 and PD-L1. By blocking that connection, these medicines remove a brake that tumors use to keep immune cells such as T cells from killing cancer cells.

Checkpoint inhibitors that target the PD-1 PD-L1 pathway are already approved for several cancers. For some people, they can produce long lasting remission. For many others, however, they provide little benefit or none at all.

Because of that gap, researchers are searching for other ways tumors suppress the immune system. One promising target involves interactions between tumor glycans and receptors on immune cells.

Siglecs, Sialic Acid, and a Sugar Based Checkpoint

Glycans appear on nearly all living cells, but cancer cells often carry versions not found on healthy cells. Many of these tumor specific glycans include a sugar building block called sialic acid. When sialic acids attach to lectin receptors on immune cells, they can switch on an immune dampening pathway. The lectins that recognize sialic acid are called Siglecs.

"When Siglecs on immune cells bind to sialic acids on cancer cells, it puts the brakes on the immune response. It prevents that immune cell from becoming activated to attack and destroy the cancer cell, just like what happens when PD-1 binds to PD-L1," Stark says.

So far, no approved medicines directly target the Siglec sialic acid interaction, even though many approaches have been explored. One idea has been to create lectins that bind to sialic acids and block their contact with immune cells. But this has struggled because lectins typically do not bind strongly enough to build up in large numbers on the surface of cancer cells.

AbLecs Combine Antibodies and Lectins

To solve that problem, Stark and her team used antibodies as delivery vehicles to bring more lectins to tumors. The antibody portion targets cancer cells, and once it arrives, the attached lectin can bind sialic acid. That blocks sialic acid from engaging Siglec receptors on immune cells, which lifts the immune brake and lets immune cells including macrophages and natural killer (NK) cells attack the tumor.

"This lectin binding domain typically has relatively low affinity, so you can't use it by itself as a therapeutic. But, when the lectin domain is linked to a high-affinity antibody, you can get it to the cancer cell surface where it can bind and block sialic acids," Stark says.

A Plug and Play Design Tested in Cells and Mice

For this study, the researchers built an AbLec using trastuzumab, an antibody that binds to HER2 and is approved for treating breast, stomach, and colorectal cancers. To create the AbLec, they replaced one arm of the antibody with a lectin, choosing either Siglec-7 or Siglec-9.

In lab experiments with cultured cells, this AbLec changed how immune cells behaved, pushing them to attack and kill cancer cells.

The team also tested the AbLecs in mice engineered to express human Siglec receptors and human antibody receptors. After the mice were given cancer cells that formed lung metastases, treatment with the AbLec led to fewer lung metastases than treatment with trastuzumab alone.

The researchers also demonstrated that the approach is flexible. They could swap in different tumor targeting antibodies such as rituximab, which targets CD20, or cetuximab, which targets EGFR. They could also exchange the lectin portion to target other immunosuppressive glycans, or use antibodies that target checkpoint proteins such as PD-1.

"AbLecs are really plug-and-play. They're modular," Stark says. "You can imagine swapping out different decoy receptor domains to target different members of the lectin receptor family, and you can also swap out the antibody arm. This is important because different cancer types express different antigens, which you can address by changing the antibody target."

Next Steps and Funding

Stark, Bertozzi, and colleagues have launched a company called Valora Therapeutics to develop lead AbLec candidates. They aim to start clinical trials in the next two to three years.

Funding for the work came in part from a Burroughs Wellcome Fund Career Award at the Scientific Interface, a Society for Immunotherapy of Cancer Steven A. Rosenberg Scholar Award, a V Foundation V Scholar Grant, the National Cancer Institute, the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, a Merck Discovery Biologics SEEDS grant, an American Cancer Society Postdoctoral Fellowship, and a Sarafan ChEM-H Postdocs at the Interface seed grant.

Title: Scientists find a weak spot in deadly fungus that shut down hospital intensive care units
Description:
Scientists have identified a genetic mechanism that could point to new ways of treating a rare but deadly fungal infection that has forced multiple hospital intensive care units to shut down. The finding offers early hope against a pathogen that has been difficult to control and nearly impossible to treat once it spreads.

Candida auris is especially dangerous for people who are already critically ill, leaving hospitals highly exposed to outbreaks. Although the fungus can exist on the skin without causing symptoms, patients who depend on ventilators face a much greater risk. Once infection occurs, about 45 percent of patients die, and the fungus is resistant to all major types of antifungal drugs. This resistance makes treatment extremely challenging and allows the pathogen to persist in hospital wards.

A global health threat with mysterious origins

The infection was first detected in 2008, and its origin is still unknown. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in more than 40 countries, including the UK. Candida auris, also called Candidozyma auris, is now recognized as a serious global health threat and appears on the World Health Organization's critical priority fungal pathogens list. In the UK, reported cases have continued to rise steadily.

Studying infection in a living model

Researchers at the University of Exeter have now taken a major step forward by examining how genes are activated during Candida auris infection. This marks the first time such genetic activity has been studied in a living host using an approach based on fish larvae. The study was published in the Nature portfolio journal Communications Biology and was supported by Wellcome, the Medical Research Council (MRC), and the National Center for Replacement, Reduction and Refinement (NC3Rs).

The researchers say the results could help identify a biological target for new antifungal treatments or even allow existing drugs to be reused, if the same genetic behavior is confirmed during infection in humans.

The project was co-led by NIHR Clinical Lecturer Hugh Gifford of the University of Exeter's MRC Center for Medical Mycology (CMM). He said: "Since it emerged, Candida auris has wreaked havoc where it takes hold in hospital intensive care units. It can be deadly for vulnerable patients, and health trusts have spent millions on the difficult job of eradication. We think our research may have revealed an Achilles heel in this lethal pathogen during active infection, and we urgently need more research to explore whether we can find drugs that target and exploit this weakness."

Why traditional research models fell short

One of the biggest obstacles in studying Candida auris has been its ability to survive high temperatures. When combined with its unusually strong tolerance for salt, this has led some researchers to suggest it may have originated in tropical oceans or marine animals. These traits also made it difficult to study using conventional laboratory models.

To overcome this, the Exeter team developed a new infection model using Arabian killifish. The eggs of this species can survive at temperatures similar to the human body, making them suitable for observing infection in conditions that closely resemble real illness.

Genetic activity reveals possible vulnerabilities

During the experiments, researchers observed that Candida auris can change its shape by forming elongated fungal structures known as filaments. These structures may help the fungus search for nutrients while infecting a host.

The team also analyzed which genes were activated or switched off during infection to identify possible weak points. Several of the genes that became active are responsible for producing nutrient pumps that capture iron-scavenging molecules and transport iron into fungal cells. Because iron is essential for survival, this process may represent a critical vulnerability.

Co-senior author Dr. Rhys Farrer of the University of Exeter's MRC Centre for Medical Mycology said: "Until now, we've had no idea what genes are active during infection of a living host. We now need to find out if this also occurs during human infection. The fact that we found genes are activated to scavenge iron gives clues to where Candida auris may originate, such as an iron-poor environment in the sea. It also gives us a potential target for new and already existing drugs."

Hope for future treatments

Dr. Gifford, who also works as a resident physician in intensive care and respiratory medicine at the Royal Devon & Exeter Hospital, emphasized the clinical importance of the findings. He said: "While there are a number of research steps to go through yet, our finding could be an exciting prospect for future treatment. We have drugs that target iron scavenging activities. We now need to explore whether they could be repurposed to stop Candida auris from killing humans and closing down hospital intensive care units."

The Arabian killifish larvae model was developed with support from an NC3Rs project grant as an alternative to using mouse and zebrafish models, which are commonly used to study interactions between pathogens and their hosts. Dr. Katie Bates, NC3Rs Head of Research Funding, said: "This new publication demonstrates the utility of the replacement model to study Candida auris infection and enable unprecedented insights into cellular and molecular events in live infected hosts. This is a brilliant example of how innovative alternative approaches can overcome key limitations of traditional animal studies."

The paper is titled 'Xenosiderophore transporter gene expression and clade-specific filamentation in Candida auris killifish (Aphanius dispar) infection' and is published in the Nature portfolio journal Communications Biology.

Title: Dinosaur bones found almost on top of each other in Transylvania
Description:
The Ha»õeg Basin in Transylvania has long been known around the world for its dinosaur fossils, uncovered at dozens of sites over the last hundred years. Even so, complete dinosaur discoveries are usually uncommon across the region. That pattern changed with the identification of a newly studied site where scientists documented more than 100 vertebrate fossils per square meter, including large dinosaur bones lying almost directly on top of one another.

Years of Fieldwork Lead to an Exceptional Fossil Find

For more than five years, the Valiora Dinosaur Research Group, made up of Hungarian and Romanian paleontologists, has been carrying out fieldwork in the western Ha»õeg Basin. The rocks examined there date back to the Upper Cretaceous and capture the final few million years before dinosaurs disappeared. Excavations have revealed fossil-rich deposits containing thousands of remains from amphibians, turtles, crocodiles, dinosaurs, pterosaurs, and mammals.

Among all the sites explored, one location known as K2 stands out. From an area measuring less than five square meters, researchers recovered more than 800 vertebrate fossils, making it the richest site documented so far. The full scientific analysis of this discovery was recently published in the journal PLOS ONE.

A Defining Moment in the Field

"In 2019, during our first field survey in the Ha»õeg Basin, we almost immediately came across the K2 site. It was a defining moment for us -- we instantly noticed dozens of large, exceptionally well-preserved black dinosaur bones gleaming in the grey clay layers exposed in the streambed. We immediately began our work, and through several years of excavation we collected an extraordinarily rich vertebrate assemblage from the site," explained G√°bor Botfalvai, assistant professor at the Department of Paleontology, E√∂tv√∂s Lor√°nd University, and leader of the research group.

How Ancient Floods Created a Bone-Rich Landscape

About 72 million years ago, the region that is now the Ha»õeg Basin experienced a warm, subtropical climate shaped by temporary river systems. These rivers flowed from higher terrain toward the basin and frequently spilled over their banks during heavy rainfall. As floodwaters surged downstream, they gathered animal carcasses from the surface, along with living creatures and skeletal remains caught in their path.

"Detailed study of the rocks at the K2 site indicates that a small lake once existed here, which was periodically fed by flash floods carrying animal carcasses. As the flow of the rivers slowed rapidly upon entering the lake, the transported bodies accumulated in the deltaic environment along the shore, producing this exceptionally high bone concentration," said Soma Budai, researcher at the University of Pavia and co-author of the publication.

Rare Dinosaur Skeletons Reveal New Scientific Insights

The K2 site produced far more than scattered bones. Researchers also identified several partial dinosaur skeletons that remained associated with one another. These fossils represent two separate plant-eating dinosaur species. One group belongs to a roughly two-meter-long dinosaur from the Rhabdodontidae family, a species commonly found in the Ha»õeg Basin that likely moved mainly on two legs.

The second group of skeletons marks a major breakthrough. These remains belong to a titanosaurian sauropod, a long-necked dinosaur for which no comparably well-preserved skeletons had ever been discovered in Transylvania. Ongoing analysis of these fossils is expected to improve scientists' understanding of how this dinosaur fits into the broader evolutionary family tree.

The Oldest Known Vertebrate Accumulation in the Basin

"Besides the remarkably high bone concentration, another key significance of this newly described site is that it represents the oldest known vertebrate accumulation in the Ha»õeg Basin. Studying this fossil assemblage allows us to look into the earliest composition of the Ha»õeg dinosaur fauna and trace the evolutionary directions and processes leading toward the dinosaurs known from younger Transylvanian sites -- revealing how these Late Cretaceous ecosystems were similar or different from one another," added Zolt√°n Csiki-Sava, associate professor at the University of Bucharest and Romanian leader of the research team.

Reconstructing Dinosaur Life in Ancient Europe

The fossils described in this study, together with discoveries still emerging from ongoing excavations in the Ha»õeg Basin, are helping scientists refine their understanding of how dinosaur communities evolved across (Eastern) Europe during the Late Cretaceous. These finds provide valuable clues about how ancient ecosystems formed, changed, and responded to environmental forces near the end of the age of dinosaurs.

The research was supported by the National Research, Development and Innovation Office of Hungary (NKFIH), the Supervisory Authority for Regulatory Affairs of Hungary, the Romanian Ministry of Research, Innovation and Digitalization, and the University of Bucharest.

Title: Axon initial segment dynamics during associative fear learning
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Nature Neuroscience

                         (2025)Cite this article


The axon initial segment (AIS) is the site of action potential generation and exhibits structural and functional plasticity upon adaptation of neuronal excitability and disease. Performing in vivo longitudinal two-photon imaging of AIS in the medial prefrontal cortex of male mice, we reveal dynamic AIS remodeling during associative fear learning and extinction. These results demonstrate that AIS plasticity is not only crucial for homeostatic adaptation but also a hallmark of memory formation.

Learning and memory are fundamental to adapt behavioral strategies in new environmental circumstances. Behavioral changes are supported by functional plasticity at the neuronal circuit level, which correlate with neuronal morphology changes1,2,3. Hence, revealing the mechanisms of experience-dependent structural plasticity in neuronal subtypes and pathways in vivo is crucial to understand the principles that link adaptive behaviors with cellular and neural circuit mechanisms of memory formation4,5.

The axon initial segment (AIS) is a specialized neuronal compartment responsible for action potential initiation, which is supported by high ion channel density6,7 rendering the AIS the final site of synaptic integration8. In addition, the AIS plays a crucial role in homeostatic maintenance of neuronal excitability and network function during sensory processing and learning9,10,11.

Ex vivo and in vitro studies identified the AIS as a site of neuronal plasticity. Changes in AIS location and length correlate with changes in neuronal excitability10,12,13. In contrast to synapse-specific weight adjustments, AIS plasticity rescales the global input‚Äìoutput function of a neuron, providing a fundamental, computationally distinct, synapse-independent plasticity mechanism during development14,15, aging16, sensory stimulation or deprivation11,17,18,19 and disease states20,21,22,23,24,25,26. In addition to homeostatic adjustments, AIS remodeling could be crucial for plasticity during learning and memory or the recruitment of individual neurons to subnetworks of shared excitability as well as memory engrams, given that AIS length adapts during NMDA receptor-mediated plasticity27. However, it remains unclear if structural AIS plasticity occurs during associative learning and memory formation in vivo due to the lack of AIS-specific longitudinal imaging techniques. We hypothesized that changes in AIS length act as a cellular mechanism of associative learning in medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), a brain area involved in adaptive threat behavior and memory formation28,29,30,31,32. Using a new longitudinal live imaging approach designed to monitor AIS in vivo, we aimed to test if AIS of mPFC neurons are plastic during fear learning and extinction.

To visualize AIS morphological changes in vivo, we used a transgenic mouse line expressing a cre-dependent Ankyrin-G-GFP (AnkG-GFP) fusion protein to label the AIS. AnkG is a scaffolding protein enriched at the AIS33, thus allowing for detailed analysis of AIS geometry (for example, length) in the AnkG-GFP mouse line34. AnkG-GFP mice were intercrossed with Cre-dependent tdTomato mice (Ai9) to visualize AIS and neuronal structures in mPFC excitatory neurons via viral expression of CaMKII-dependent Cre recombinase (Fig. 1a). Ex vivo immunofluorescence verified that the AIS label (GFP) colocalized with AnkG and Nav1.6 channels across its entire length (Fig. 1b, stimulated emission depletion (STED) imaging to verify the overlap of AnkG and Nav1.6 in the mPFC of wild-type mice; Extended Data Fig. 1). AnkG and sodium channel 1.6 (Nav1.6) channels are both enriched at the AIS35, verifying the specificity of the approach34. To monitor the same AIS longitudinally in vivo during associative learning, we used two-photon imaging through an aberration-corrected gradient refractive index (GRIN)-lens-based endoscope36,37 together with auditory fear conditioning and extinction as well as steady-state days where mice were not exposed to the behavioral paradigm or any changes as a control for plasticity effects (Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 2).

Mice underwent a four-day fear conditioning and extinction paradigm in which they learned to associate a mild foot shock (unconditioned stimulus, US) with an auditory cue (conditioned stimulus, CS+). During fear extinction, animals were reexposed to repeated CS+ resulting in extinction of conditioned freezing behavior. Each freely moving fear conditioning and extinction session was followed by head-fixed two-photon imaging to visualize and track AIS length of mPFC neurons, while the final 3 days of steady-state two-photon imaging were devoid of any cues or contextual elements to test for potential learning-unrelated changes in AIS length (Fig. 1c). Two-photon volume scans were performed in mPFC (Fig. 1d, predominantly the infralimbic subdivision, N‚Äâ=‚Äâ6 mice) and individual AIS were longitudinally visualized across the learning paradigm (Fig. 1e).

Next, we measured AIS length in vivo (Methods) across habituation and extinction days 1 and 2 to test how AIS length changes with learning (Fig. 2a). AIS were sampled from different imaging planes and depth similarly for all mice (Fig. 2b). Before learning during the habituation day, AIS length did not differ between mice (number of AIS: 2.06‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.12 AIS per imaging plane per mouse, Fig. 2c and Extended Data Fig. 3; mean normalized AIS length change: ‚àí0.002‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.017, Fig. 2c, Methods and equation (1)). Upon fear conditioning, animals acquired a freezing response to the CS+ (CS+ freezing: 68.7‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ9.7%, CS‚àí freezing: 30.1‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ12.2%, N‚Äâ=‚Äâ6 mice, Fig. 2d and Extended Data Fig. 1c). Upon CS+ reexposure during the first fear extinction session, mice showed initially high CS+ selective freezing levels indicating fear memory consolidation (Extinction 1 early CS+ freezing: 42.6‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ2.5% versus CS‚àí freezing: 10.2‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ1.3%, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.12‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí5, Mann‚ÄìWhitney U test, N‚Äâ=‚Äâ6 mice, Extended Data Fig. 1b), which extinguished during consecutive CS+ presentations and consolidated overnight (Extinction 1 early versus Extinction 1 late: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.04‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí4, Extinction 1 early versus Extinction 2 early: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ4.59‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí4, Extinction 1 early versus Extinction 2 late: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ2.83‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí5, Kruskal‚ÄìWallis test (P‚Äâ=‚Äâ4.47‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí5) with Dunn's post hoc correction, Fig. 2d). After each behavioral training session (except fear conditioning), AIS were visualized under a two-photon microscope to relate behavioral changes with AIS length changes. At the population level, AIS significantly elongated following the second day of fear extinction learning relative to habituation day (Habituation versus Extinction 1, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.938, Habituation versus Extinction 2, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.0072, Extinction 1 versus Extinction 2, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.024, Kruskal‚ÄìWallis test (P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.0034) test with Dunn's post hoc correction, Fig. 2e and Extended Data Fig. 4). During subsequent nonlearning, steady-state imaging days, where animals were not exposed to any learning session, average AIS length returned to its original size and remained steady throughout subsequent imaging days (Habituation day before fear conditioning versus Steady-state days 1, 2 and 3: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.978, Kruskal‚ÄìWallis test, Fig. 2e and Extended Data Fig. 4). Taken together, this indicates that following fear extinction learning, the average AIS length in mPFC increases, while AIS are stable outside of the conditioning paradigm, suggesting that structural changes at the AIS are a cellular correlate of learning-related plasticity in mPFC.

To investigate the dynamics of individual AIS across fear learning and extinction, we subsampled AIS that could be longitudinally tracked throughout all imaging sessions (60 out of an average of 268 daily imaged AIS, 22%) and measured their length relative to the habituation session (Fig. 3a). K-means clustering revealed four distinct clusters of dynamic changes of AIS length (Fig. 3b). The largest group (43.3%), termed elongated cluster, increased in length (36.4‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ5.3% relative length change to habituation after Extinction 2) following fear extinction learning, which was in line with the general population average. However, opposed to the average population dynamics (Fig. 2), AIS length did not return to baseline after extinction consolidation but maintained its elongated state (Elongated cluster Habituation versus Steady-state day 1: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ3.24‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí5, Habituation versus Steady-state day 2: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ2.56‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí4, Habituation versus Steady-state day 3: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ6.21‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí5, Kruskal‚ÄìWallis test (P‚Äâ=‚Äâ2.04‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí6) with Dunn's post hoc correction, Fig. 3b).

A second, smaller cluster contained AIS (16.7%, shortened cluster) that exhibited a decrease in length (‚àí15.8‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ4.3%) following fear extinction. This decrease was less pronounced relative to the change observed for the elongated cluster and AIS tended to return to their original length during steady-state sessions. Additionally, we observed two stable clusters. These clusters exhibited initially slight decreases (stable cluster 1: relative change: ‚àí3.6‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ2.0%, 21.6% of AIS) or increases in length (stable cluster 2: relative change: 10.9‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ2.6%, 18.3% of AIS) after conditioning. However, these AIS reverted to their original length and maintained it throughout subsequent sessions. The across-day length change during learning for stable clusters was not significantly different to the total change across days during steady-state sessions, indicating that the length change observed for stable clusters was not different to changes in length that AIS undergo during nonlearning conditions. However, the change in length was significantly different between steady-state days and elongated or shortened plastic clusters (Steady state versus Stable 1: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.99, Steady state versus Stable 2: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.99, Steady state versus Elongated: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ2.23‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí7, Steady state versus Shortened: P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.011, Kruskal‚ÄìWallis test (P‚Äâ=‚Äâ7.28‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí11), Dunn's post hoc correction, Fig. 3c). Overall, we observed diverse plasticity of AIS length following fear extinction learning (Extended Data Fig. 5). AIS of mPFC excitatory neurons exhibited significant learning-dependent length changes relative to preconditioning states. The elongated cluster contained both the highest AIS number and maintained an increase in length throughout all imaging days. Finally, tracking AIS plasticity cluster composition by initial length revealed that elongated and shortened AIS clusters originate from the pool of shortest or longest AIS, respectively (Fig. 3d, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ7.44‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ10‚àí4, Mann‚ÄìWhitney U test), suggesting that AIS length changes occur within a predetermined physiological dynamic range in mPFC, beyond which elongation or shortening does not result in additional changes to neuronal excitability38,39.

To test if AIS length is linked to neuronal activity, we combined two-photon calcium imaging of mPFC excitatory neurons with post hoc AIS length measurements. Mice were exposed to the fear learning and extinction paradigm as described. Following the second day of extinction, spontaneous neuronal activity of mPFC neurons was measured with the red-shifted calcium indicator R-GECO and AIS length measured subsequently in horizontal brain slices ex vivo (Fig. 4a‚Äìd). Thirty-eight neurons from three mice could be matched between in vivo two-photon imaging and post hoc ex vivo fluorescence microscopy. Interestingly, in vivo calcium event rates of individual neurons did not significantly correlate with AIS length (Extended Data Fig. 6). However, AIS length positively correlated with the area under the curve of individual calcium events (Fig. 4e) indicating that increased AIS length is associated with bursts of high frequency action potentials in mPFC neurons.

Finally, we tested if AIS length is associated with memory allocation. Mice were exposed to the fear conditioning and extinction paradigm (Fig. 4f and Extended Data Fig. 7a) and subsequently perfused. This approach prevented us following individual AIS in vivo, yet provided access to large numbers of neurons. Strikingly, we found that AIS of c-Fos+ neurons (Fig. 4g) exhibited a large distribution of AIS lengths, including neurons with very short and very long AIS in infralimbic cortex after fear extinction (Fig. 4h). In contrast, this difference could not be observed in prelimbic cortex, a brain area thought to be involved in fear recall40 (Fig. 4i and Extended Data Fig. 7b,c). These findings suggest that dynamic changes in infralimbic cortex AIS length upon fear extinction occur in c-Fos-activated ensembles, which are enriched with shortened and lengthened AIS. These changes in AIS length will allow for neuronal output adjustments during engram formation upon extinction memory recall, a function that was previously associated with infralimbic cortex39. Additionally, this effect is brain area- and learning-specific, given that differences in AIS lengths of c-Fos+ neurons could not be observed in prelimbic cortex after extinction learning (see above), yet emerged after fear recall training (Extended Data Fig. 7). This supports the notion that AIS length is dynamic upon learning and plasticity-inducing events in an engram- and brain area-specific fashion.

mPFC pyramidal neurons have previously been identified as a site of functional plasticity during extinction learning41. Using an AIS marker line and GRIN-lens-based two-photon imaging, we visualized and tracked AIS length longitudinally across a 4-day fear conditioning and extinction paradigm. We identified population level changes in AIS length upon fear extinction learning. Overall, increased AIS length was associated with fear extinction learning. Nevertheless, at the single cell level, distinct clusters of mPFC neurons with elongated or shortened AIS emerged upon extinction learning, suggesting that AIS length changes could map onto distinct populations of mPFC pyramidal neurons42,43,44,45 recruiting them into opposing functional ensembles with increased or decreased excitability. Therefore, bidirectional AIS plasticity could be a mechanism to counterbalance the weight between distinct mPFC subnetworks, for example, neurons of functionally distinct output pathways or opposing engrams for the formation and extinction of associative memories41,44,46.

Indeed, neurons of the elongated cluster did not revert their AIS length post-extinction learning, suggesting that persistent AIS elongation of this cluster is associated with elevated excitability and supports long term extinction memory in mPFC networks41,47,48,49.

Interestingly, before associative learning, AIS recruited into the elongated cluster tend to be shorter while those recruited to the shortened cluster tend to be longer, suggesting that AIS length changes occur most dynamically at the extreme ends of the length distribution within a defined dynamic range and structural limitation, where they might exert their strongest impact on action potential initiation and excitability38,39. Prelearning AIS length might thus be a hallmark of availability for neuronal plasticity of mPFC pyramidal neurons and their recruitment to memory engrams. This is further supported by our finding that infralimbic c-Fos+ neurons exhibit a broader AIS length distribution than c-Fos‚àí neurons following fear extinction learning, suggesting that fear extinction engrams are linked to both, elongation and shortening of AIS clusters. AIS length-dependent up- or downregulation of neuronal excitability within c-Fos+ engrams would be crucial to mediate distinct mPFC-output pathways that drive learning-specific behaviors. In contrast, c-Fos‚àí neurons are typically not considered part of an engram and exhibited a narrower AIS length distribution after learning. This could result from both, neurons that did not change their AIS length and neurons that adjusted their AIS length toward the mean of the c-Fos‚àí population, which might be a potential homeostatic mechanism balancing activity and dampening output of the non-engram network. Together, our findings support the notion that learning is dependent on bidirectional control of AIS length and in turn adaptive neuronal activity within the memory engram to balance the activity of neuronal types with distinct functions.

Here we have shown that dynamic changes in AIS length occur during associative learning and extinction in vivo and might be a cellular mechanism of plasticity regulation during memory formation. Together with recent ex vivo studies, this suggests that AIS length changes might be a general mechanism for plasticity regulation and memory formation in other brain areas and behaviors beyond mPFC and fear learning, respectively11,27,50,51. Furthermore, AIS dynamics could contribute to both the formation of specific cue-driven changes in the input‚Äìoutput function of tuned neurons as well as the regulation of excitability in behavior-specific neuronal ensembles or memory engrams driving behavior and memory recall in a state-dependent fashion52,53,54,55. Given that the AIS is perturbed in a number of neurological diseases21,23,24,25,26, including neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer's disease56, maladaptation of AIS plasticity might play an important role in disorders of memory loss, cognitive decline and behavioral changes long before neuronal cell loss occurs.

Experiments were performed in accordance with the institutional guidelines of the University of Basel (Tierschutz) and the German Center for Neurodegenerative Disorders, and were approved by the Cantonal Veterinary Office of Basel-Stadt and the Landesamt f√ºr Natur-, Umwelt- und Verbraucherschutz NRW. Experiments were conducted in 9‚Äì15-week-old male C57Bl/6‚ÄâJ, AnkG-GFP or AnkG-GFP::Ai9 mice. Cre-dependent AnkG-GFP mice (B6;129SV-ank3tm1DCI/HD) were provided by Maren Engelhardt, Johannes Kepler University Linz34. AnkG-GFP mice were crossed with Cre-dependent tdTomato reporter (Ai9) mice (Gt(ROSA)26Sortm9(CAG-tdTomato)Hze, JAX: IMSR_JAX:007909 (ref. 57)) to generate the AnkG-GFP::Ai9 mice. Mice were housed on a 12-hour light/dark cycle and had ad libitum access to food and water.

Systemic analgesia (0.1‚Äâmg kg‚àí1 buprenorphine, subcutaneous (s.c.)) was provided 30‚Äâmin before the start of the surgery. Mice were anesthetized with isoflurane (4% induction, 1.5‚Äì2.0% maintenance, Henry Schein) in oxygen-enriched air (95%, Oxymat III, Weinmann). Stereotactic surgeries were performed with a high-precision stereotaxic apparatus (Model 1900, Kopf Instruments). Body temperature was maintained at ca. 36‚Äâ¬∞C (Rodent warmer, 53800‚ÄâM, Stoelting) and eyes were covered with a protective cream (Bepanthen, Bayer). Local analgesia was provided s.c. above the skull before incision of the skin (Lidocain (10‚Äâmg per kg) and Ropivacain (Naropin, 3‚Äâmg per kg)). Viral vectors (250‚Äânl AAV2/retro.mCaMKII.iCre.WPRE-hGHp(A), VVF Zurich and 250‚Äânl, AAV1.Syn.NES-jRGECO1a.WPrE.SV40, Addgene 100854-AAV1 for in vivo recordings of neuronal activity) were injected at coordinates AP 1.8, ML ‚àí0.35, DV ‚àí2.0‚Äâmm with the help of a hydraulic micropositioner (Model 2650, Kopf) with a pulled glass pipette (2-000-0001, Drummond Scientific) and a pressure ejection system (Picospritzer, Parker). Meloxicam (Metacam, 5‚Äâmg per kg, s.c.) was injected as postoperative analgesia once a day for 3 consecutive days after surgery.

An aberration-corrected GRIN lens (diameter 0.5‚Äâmm, length 4.07‚Äâmm, focal length in water immersion 200‚Äâ¬µm)36,37 was implanted during a second surgery (anesthesia and analgesia as previously described). A small craniotomy was drilled (Kyocera) above the virus injection coordinates, and a small track was cut with a 0.7‚Äâmm sterile needle (22‚ÄâG, Terumo). The GRIN lens was then slowly advanced into the brain (DV ‚àí2.2‚Äâmm) and fixed to the skull with ultra violet light curable glue (Loctite 4305, Henkel). The skin was sealed with Scotchbond (3‚ÄâM). A stainless-steel head bar (custom made) was attached to the skull to fix the animal during imaging sessions by using Vetbond (3‚ÄâM) and dental acrylic (Paladur, Kulzer).

Behavioral experiments were performed during the animal's light period. Mice were acclimatized to the experimenter, two-photon scanning and head fixation for 3 days. Next, a 4-day auditory fear conditioning paradigm was performed in a habituation/test context (days 1, 3 and 4) and a fear conditioning context (day 2). During the habituation session (30‚Äâmin), mice were presented with 5 intermingled CS+ and CS‚àí (5 each, 12‚ÄâkHz and 6‚ÄâkHz, respectively) in a round plexiglass context (low light conditions, 1% acetic acid isoamyl ester). CSs were composed of 27 tone pips (200‚Äâms, 75‚ÄâdB) presented at a rate of 1.1‚ÄâHz (Tucker Davis Technologies, RZ6). Fear conditioning was performed in a 25‚Äâcm-square plexiglass box with a shock grid floor (Coulbourn, Noldus, bright light conditions, 70% ethanol smell, 0‚Äâmin). Five CS+ were terminated by a 2‚Äâs, 0.65-mA foot shock immediately after the last tone pip and intermingled with five CS‚àí presentations. During fear extinction learning sessions (days 3 and day 4, 35‚Äâmin), mice were presented with 4 CS‚àí and 12 CS+ in the habituation context. Immediately after each behavioral session, except for fear conditioning, mice were head fixed under a two-photon microscope for a structural scan of AIS. Steady-state sessions (days 5‚Äì7) were conducted after the fear extinction days during which mice were imaged similarly to the habituation and learning days. Fear conditioning experiments were performed using Ethovision XT 14 (Noldus). Behavioral tracking was conducted using DeepLabCut58. Freezing was detected automatically based on periods of absence of movement (threshold: 1‚Äâs) and checked manually for non-freezing episodes (for example, grooming) post hoc.

In vivo two-photon imaging was performed using a custom-built two-photon microscope (Independent NeuroScience Services). Mice were head fixed with a custom-designed head bar system and placed on a running wheel during imaging. The microscope was equipped with a resonant scanning system (CRS08K, Cambridge Technology) and a pulsed Ti:sapphire laser (Chameleon Vision S, Coherent) and controlled by ScanImage software (Version 5.7, Vidrio Technologies). We used a water dipping objective lens (N16XLWD-PF - 16X CFI LWD, 0.80 NA, Nikon) to focus on the back end of the aberration-corrected GRIN endoscope36,37. The light path included a dichroic mirror (T565lpxr, long pass, Chroma), barrier filters (green: ET510/80‚Äâm, red: ET630/75‚Äâm, Chroma) and photomultiplier tubes (PMT2101, Thorlabs). For both fluorescence channels, images were acquired at a resolution of 512‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ512 pixels, with 940‚Äânm excitation and 30 frames per second. For calcium imaging experiments, the spontaneous activity of mPFC excitatory neurons was recorded via two-photon imaging of the calcium indicator R-GECO, over 10‚Äâmin, following the second day of fear extinction learning. Images were acquired at a resolution of 512‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ512 pixels, with 1,020‚Äânm excitation and 30 frames per second. All mice were habituated to the experimenter, head restraint and two-photon imaging in the same imaging setup for several days before the imaging experiments.

Corrected GRIN lenses were used to reduce effects of optical aberrations36,37. Two-photon z-stack dual-color images (green or red) were acquired along a volume of ~400‚Äâ¬µm (5-¬µm step, 250 frames per plane). After acquisition, the images were motion corrected using Matlab code adapted from Suite2P59. The images of each channel were mean projected and merged to create dual-color images using ImageJ (Version 2.0). Signal intensities in both green and red channels were adjusted in ImageJ for visualization purpose by saturating the brightest 35% of the pixels per channel, per imaging plane to maintain an unbiased transformation between planes. Using Simple Neurite Tracer (SNT, ImageJ 2.0), AIS visible on the green channel but not red channel (Extended Data Fig. 8 shows examples of visual differences) were manually marked on each of the green channel images and a fitted path was applied to allow the measurement of AIS length. For GRIN-2P in vivo imaging, AIS start and end were visually defined by the experimenter as a sharp change of fluorescence in the in vivo 2P image. mPFC AIS typically start at the soma indicated by a sharp rise in fluorescence (Extended Data Fig. 9). For individual mice, in vivo imaged AIS were aligned manually across a number of days. For ex vivo confocal imaging, AIS intensity data was filtered using a Savitzky-Golay filter. The AIS location was defined as a rigid 80% drop from the peak fluorescence for confocal images. Analysis and measurement of the AIS (in pixels) were performed in a blinded manner by several experimenters with the identity of mice and experimental day unknown during AIS measurements. Only AIS whose entire length was fully contained in a single optical plane (that is, individual z-stack frame) were tracked for further analysis. For calcium imaging experiments, Suite2p was used to extract calcium traces of individual neurons. False positives were discarded and cells were defined manually if these were not detected automatically. Neuropil signal around each cell was multiplied by 0.7 and subtracted from the calcium trace with the result considered as the calcium signal of a single neuron. For ex vivo imaging of c-Fos expression and AIS length, images were acquired with an LSM900 confocal microscope (Zeiss). Confocal images were postprocessed with ImageJ (Version 2.0). For quantification and thresholding of c-Fos expression, the ImageJ plugin Quanty-cFOS60 was used, and the SNT61 plugin was utilized to track AIS.

For in vivo‚Äìex vivo alignment experiments, matching between two-photon fields of view and ex vivo horizontal mPFC images was achieved by performing a 2D z-projection in ImageJ of manually selected confocal planes. The planes were manually selected by identifying topological hallmarks present in both the two-photon and the confocal images.

Finally, for super-resolution imaging, a STED microscopy setup was used (Facility Line, Abberior Instruments). The setup is built on a motorized inverse microscope body (IX83, Olympus) and equipped with a pulsed 775-nm depletion laser and 405-nm, 485-nm, 561-nm and 640-nm excitation lasers. Spectral detection was performed using single-photon-counting avalanche photodiode detectors. Acquisition was normalized to 5‚Äì15 photons per pixel and Œºs with a pixel dwell time of 5‚ÄâŒºs. Channel-specific line accumulation was individually adapted to reach a photon count above 100 within the brightest pixels per field of view. Spectral windows were set to 410‚Äì470‚Äânm for Alexa405Plus, 510‚Äì600‚Äânm for 460‚ÄâL, 600‚Äì630‚Äânm for StarOrange and 650‚Äì725‚Äânm for StarRed fluorophors. Images were acquired using a √ó60 oil immersion objective (1.45 NA, UPLXAPO60XO, Olympus) and a set lateral pixel size of 20‚Äânm.

Due to the internal magnification of GRIN lenses and optical nonuniformities62,63, in vivo AIS lengths are provided as relative changes to themselves, providing an accurate way of comparing AIS across different planes and samples. The start and the end of the AIS were defined visually by the experimenter in two-photon in vivo images. To compare changes in AIS length relative to the first imaging session (habituation, Fig. 2d) the mean of AIS length during the habituation session was calculated per mouse. Next this value was subtracted from each individual AIS length per mouse and the result divided by the same mean value using equation (1) as follows:

To calculate the mean change in AIS length within steady-state sessions versus the change in length within the learning phase for each plasticity cluster (Fig. 3c), the normalized AIS length (the relative length change to habituation session) was summed across steady-state sessions and across the learning phase of each plasticity cluster per individual AIS (i) and divided by the number of sessions according to equation (2):

where for the learning phase n equals Extinction session 1 and n‚Äâ+‚Äâ1 equals Extinction session 2 and for the steady-state phase n equals Steady day 1 and n‚Äâ+‚Äâ1 equals Steady day 2. The resulting session change values were averaged per cluster.

Following completion of behavioral experiments, mice were transcardially perfused with around 5‚Äâml phosphate buffered saline (PBS, ThermoFisher) followed by 20‚Äâml 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) in PBS (pH‚Äâ=‚Äâ7.4). Brains were removed and stored overnight in 4% PFA. Coronal slices (150‚ÄâŒºm) were prepared using a vibratome (Leica Biosystems VT1000S) and immunostained for AnkG and Nav1.6 using the following solutions and protocol: carrier solution: 1% normal horse serum (Vector Laboratories) with 0.5% Triton (ThermoFisher) in PBS (ThermoFisher), blocking solution: 10% normal horse serum with 0.5% Triton in PBS, PBST solution: 0.1% Triton in PBS. After 3 rounds of PBS washes, slices were blocked for 2‚Äâh at room temperature and incubated in primary antibodies in carrier solution (guinea pig anti-AnkG, 1:500, Synaptic Systems, cat. no. 386005; rabbit anti-Nav1.6, 1:150, Alomone, cat. no. ASC-009) overnight at 4‚Äâ¬∞C. Slices were washed again 3 times in PBST and incubated for 2‚Äâh at room temperature in secondary antibodies in carrier solution (goat DyLight405 anti-guinea pig, 1:400, Jackson ImmunoResearch, cat. no. 160-475-003; goat AlexaFluor467 anti-rabbit, 1:400, Invitrogen, cat. no. A21244). After 3 final washes, slices were mounted on slides and cover slipped using 22‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ50‚Äâmm, 0.16‚Äì0.19-mm-thick cover glass (FisherScientific). Images were acquired with an LSM700 upright confocal microscope (Zeiss). Confocal images were postprocessed with ImageJ (Version 2.0). The confocal tile scan overview image in Fig. 4d was adjusted for differences in contrast and brightness of different planes at tile edges in a plane-by-plane manner. This adjustment was not required for the quantification of individual AIS at high magnification.

For c-Fos experiments, timed perfusions were carried out 90‚Äâmin after the start of the behavior for each animal, which included a 20-min home cage period after the end of the behavioral session. Brain tissue was kept in 4% PFA. Coronal sections of mPFC of 100‚Äâ¬µm were prepared with a Leica VT1000S vibratome. Antibody staining protocols were the same as described. Antibodies: c-Fos: rat anti-c-Fos, 1:1000, Synaptic Systems, cat. no. 226017; secondary antibody: Alexa Fluor Plus 555 donkey anti-rat, 1:1000, Invitrogen, cat. no. A48270. AnkG was co-stained as described.

For the experiments where in vivo neural activity was matched to ex vivo AIS length, tissue sectioning was performed in the horizontal plane (200‚ÄâŒºm thickness). The immunostaining procedure to label AnkG was the same as described.

For 2D-STED microscopy, tissue after perfusion was embedded in OCT compound (Tissue Tek, Sakura Finetek) and lowered into ‚àí160‚Äâ¬∞C isopentane for quick, unidirectional freezing. Coronal slices (40‚ÄâŒºm) were prepared using a cryostat (Leica Biosystems CM3050 S) and transferred directly into 2% PFA for 10‚Äâmin. After washing in PBS, slices were incubated in blocking buffer (1% BSA, 0.2% fish skin gelatine, 0.1% Triton in 0.1‚ÄâM PBS) for 60‚Äâmin and subsequently incubated in primary antibodies (guinea pig anti-AnkG, 1:1,000, Synaptic Systems, cat. no. 386005; rabbit anti-Nav1.6, 1:500, Alomone, cat. no. ASC-009; rabbit anti-c-Fos, 1:500, Cell Signaling, cat. no. 2250; chicken anti-NeuN, 1:1,000, cat. no. 266006, Synaptic Systems) overnight at 4‚Äâ¬∞C. After 3 rounds of PBS washes, slices were incubated for 2‚Äâh in secondary antibodies (Alexa 405 Plus goat anti-chicken, 1:1000, Invitrogen, cat. no. A48254; Star 460‚ÄâL goat anti-rabbit, 1:1,000, Abberior, cat. no. ST460L-1002; StarOrange goat anti-mouse, 1:1,000, Abberior, cat. no. STORANGE-1001; StarRed goat anti-guinea pig, 1:1,000, Abberior, cat. no. STRED-1006) at room temperature. Slices were washed again 3 times in PBS, mounted in an aqueous embedding medium (Abberior Mount Solid Antifade, Abberior GmbH) and cover slipped using precision cover glasses with a thickness of 0.170‚Äâmm‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.05‚Äâmm (Paul Marienfeld GmbH).

Statistical analysis was performed using Matlab (Mathworks) and Python (Version 3.8, Python Software Foundation including SciPy and scikit-learn). Normality was tested using the D'Agostino and Pearson's test. To identify groups of AIS with distinct length dynamics, k-means clustering using the k-means+ plus initialization method (Python and scikit-learn) and a restriction to four clusters was applied. Additional attempts at increasing the number of clusters resulted in the formation of subclusters that were still part of the four primary ones. For analysis of AIS length comparing c-Fos+ and c-Fos‚àí cells, Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov test and CDF analysis were used. Values are presented as mean‚Äâ¬±‚Äâs.e.m. unless stated otherwise. Box and whisker plots indicate mean (dot) and median (horizontal line), interquartile range as well as the minimum to maximum value of the distribution. No statistical methods were used to predetermine sample sizes but our sample sizes are similar to those reported in previous publications in the field. Animals were randomly added to experimental groups without preselection. All animals with visible AIS were included in the experiments and analysis, except one mouse which only had two visible AISs. Micrographs in Fig. 1a could be repeated in N‚Äâ=‚Äâ10 mice. Micrographs in Fig. 1b could be repeated for n‚Äâ=‚Äâ5 AIS from N‚Äâ=‚Äâ1 mouse (Extended Data Fig. 1. The overlap of AnkG and Nav channels was established previously34). Statistical tests are given in the text or figure legends. *, ** and *** indicate P values smaller than 0.05, 0.01 and 0.001, respectively.

Title: High-throughput triazole-based combinatorial click chemistry for the synthesis and identification of functional metal complexes
Description:
